title: Heart rate variability (HRV)
content: In this AMA episode, Peter and Bob first answer a variety of questions related to heart rate variability (HRV): what it means, why it matters, and how to measure, interpret, and potentially elevate it. They discuss factors that can raise or lower HRV, how and when to measure HRV, and the best wearables. They also talk about interpreting your personal HRV number and why there’s so much individual variation.

title: Alcohol and Sleep
content: Peter and Bob discuss the negative impact that alcohol can have on sleep, including its impact on the need to urinate during the night. They also talk about metrics to track the impact of alcohol on your sleep.

title: Moderate Alcohol Consumption
content: Peter and Bob analyze epidemiology studies suggesting moderate alcohol consumption lowers mortality risk. They also discuss alcohol consumption and Alzheimer’s disease, as well as heavy alcohol consumption and risk of dementia.

title: Chronic Effects of Alcohol
content: Peter and Bob discuss the chronic effects of alcohol on the liver, including alcoholic fatty liver disease (AFLD).

title: What is HRV?
content: HRV stands for heart rate variability. HRV measures the variation in time between heartbeats, and that’s measured in milliseconds. In other words, there is actually some variability. If you now measure the distance between the Rs—the RR interval—and you take the RMSSD (The Root Mean Square of Successive Differences between normal heartbeats)…that means you calculate the time difference between each RR interval. The RMSSD is obtained by first calculating each successive time difference between heartbeats (RR intervals) in ms. Then, each of the values is squared and the result is averaged before the square root of the total is obtained. So RMSSD is reported in milliseconds. If using wearables that calculate HRV while you’re sleeping, you’ll notice it gives you a number in milliseconds.

title: What is HRV and how does it relate to the autonomic nervous system?
content: HRV provides a snapshot into how your body is balancing between the two branches of your autonomic nervous system: sympathetic (“fight-or-flight”), and parasympathetic (“rest-and-digest”). The heart is not a metronome – it’s actually erratic. A healthy nervous system has a balanced but strong push and pull between Sympathetic and Parasympathetic causing high Heart Rate Variability. It turns out that that variability is heavily influenced by which of the autonomic nervous systems is most dominant. The Autonomic system handles the unconscious processes (and even effects conscious behavior). Autonomic contains two branches – the Parasympathetic and the Sympathetic. Sympathetic is activated in times of stress. Parasympathetic is activated in times of recovery.

title: How does HRV relate to mortality risk?
content: There’s not a lot of data, despite what people might have you believe about RMSSD, and heart rate variability, and mortality in normal populations. But there are cohort studies that look at this and try to impute patterns. The ARIC study found that in people who had an HRV (using the rMSSD method from a two-minute rhythm strip on a 12-lead EKG) of less than 14.7 millisecond compared to those who had an HRV between 14.7 and 22.3 milliseconds, the study found a greater risk of all-cause mortality (ACM) by about 95%, cerebrovascular mortality by 280%, and cancer mortality by 70% (barely significant). There was no difference in CHD in the two groups. A meta-analysis from 2013 found that a low HRV (10th percentile) was associated with a 50% increased risk [1.50 (95% CI 1.22, 1.83)] of a first cardiovascular event in people without CVD compared to those in the 50th percentile.

title: Association between HRV and mortality
content: Low HRV is associated with an increased mortality in people with heart disease, possibly cancer. Higher HRV compared to intermediate levels has a less clear benefit. There was no significant difference for all-cause mortality, cerebrovascular mortality, cancer mortality, or coronary artery disease incidents in those who had an HRV above 22.3, compared to those who were 14.7 to 22.3. In other words, what mattered most is if you were above 14.7 (in the ARIC study-which represents less the 50th percentile and likely closer to the 27%). But once you’re above, there doesn’t seem to be any additional benefit to being above 22.3.

title: High and low HRV and its correlation with sports performance
content: HRV can be a metric for measuring how ready your body is to adapt, and ultimately perform, in sports. High HRV means you’re getting both strong “on” and “off” outputs and your body is highly responsive to your environment. It can quickly shift its energy from “fight or flight” to “rest and digest” to easily match its surroundings. Low HRV generally indicates a sympathetic dominance. However, in rare instances or particular instances where you can have a low heart rate and a low HRV, which usually it’s a parasympathetic dominance which seems like it’s relatively rare.

title: Factors that can raise or lower HRV
content: Alcohol and stress can lower HRV.

title: Factors that affect HRV
content: Factors that can lower HRV include stress, smoking, lack of physical activity, poor diet, caffeine consumption in the evening, high blood pressure, high triglycerides, metabolic syndrome, and air pollution. On the other hand, endurance exercise, yoga, meditation, and biofeedback can raise HRV.

title: Measuring HRV
content: The gold standard for measuring HRV is a multi-lead ECG, but wearables that use photoplethysmography (PPG) are more common. PPG devices include chest sensors, wrist/arm sensors, ring sensors, and finger sensors. Oura stands out for its accuracy, as it uses an infrared PPG that measures off arterials, making it more accurate than other devices that measure on the venous side of the capillaries.

title: Interpreting HRV numbers
content: There is no clear answer to what is a good or bad HRV number. However, if you believe that there is a causal relationship between HRV and mortality, then a number below 14.7 would not be good.

title: HRV and Age
content: HRV declines with age so whenever you talk about HRV, you have to talk about it in the context of age. The upper curve is showing you where 75% of the population fall below, and the lower curve is showing you the upper limit of the 25% of the population. At 20 years old, the upper portion is about 105 milliseconds, the lower portion is about 60 milliseconds, the midpoint is about 80 milliseconds. By the time you’re 50, that midpoint is about 40 milliseconds, the lower point is about 30 milliseconds, the upper point is about 50 milliseconds. Looking at the rMSSD column, in the 10 to 19 range, it’s actually saying the mean is 53 plus or minus 17. Though it’s slightly different than the graph above (Figure 2), it’s a little more in line with the graph when you get into upper age ranges. For example, for a 50-year-old, we would say 25 plus or minus nine—So 25 is the arithmetic mean of the population with a standard deviation of nine.

title: Genetics and HRV
content: Genetics/heritability may account for a quarter to more than half of the interindividual variation in HRV. When you do those types of analyses, we see that a HRV is somewhere between 40 and 50% genetic. A person who has always been at the 25th percentile is probably always going to be at the 25th percentile — like height, you’re not going to do a lot to change that. Among 427 European twin pairs and 308 Aftican-American twin pairs, it was determined that the genetic influence on HRV during stress is largely similar compared to rest. Among 218 identical twins, 301 fraternal twins, and 253 non-twin siblings, genetic contribution of HRV (using RMSSD) was estimated to be 40-48%. In a comparison of twins and non-twin siblings, heritability of HRV was estimated to be between 46-57% with little variation of heritability estimates for day vs night. In a study of 282 identical and 229 fraternal twin pairs, heritability was estimated to be 47% to 64%, and more than 90% of genetic influence was estimated to be shared across different components of HRV.

title: Using HRV as a Relative Measure
content: HRV (rMSSD) appears to be more useful as a relative measure rather than an absolute measure. It’s easy to get hung up on your number relative to somebody else’s. What’s a more useful endeavor is to know that, “Hey, over the past five years I’ve been tracking my HRV, and I know what makes it ebb and flow. And I know that when it’s low for me, I know how I can act on that.”

title: Peter's Metrics for Readiness to Train
content: Before there was HRV, when Peter was growing up and training really hard, he used two metrics assessed in the morning to gauge readiness for exercise. Bob asks Peter whether his HRV score from the night of sleep impacts his decision to train/exercise that day… Peter response: “No. It definitely doesn’t influence my decision to train because I’m going to train every single day.”

title: Willingness to Exercise
content: Your willingness to train matters a lot, especially when you are run down. Pay attention to your subjective feeling of not wanting to exercise for a day. Peter Attia pays slightly more attention to that than to his HRV.

title: Alcohol's Impact on Sleep
content: Alcohol negatively impacts sleep. It's a sedative that works like sleeping pills, fragments sleep, and blocks REM sleep. It reduces the quality of sleep, which has implications for disease. It impacts resting heart rate, heart rate variability, respiratory rate, and body temperature. It's a function of how much you drink and when you drink in relation to sleep.

title: Alcohol's impact on sleep
content: After two drinks, Peter's resting heart rate goes up by 6-8 beats per minute, heart rate variability is compressed by 20-25% or even up to 50%, respiratory rate goes up by 2 breaths per minute, and body temperature goes up by 0.3-0.6 °F. These metrics are suggestive of more sympathetic tone, which is the underlying issue. Elevated RHR can be an indicator of other health problems, but not a problem in and of itself. With raised HR and raised core body temp., you get more fragmented sleep, more awakenings, and disruption of REM sleep. Peter uses a cooling device for sleeping to drop his core body temperature by 2-3 °F to initiate sleep.

title: Alcohol's impact on nocturia
content: Alcohol inhibits a hormone called vasopressin, which is the antidiuretic hormone. If you inhibit the antidiuretic hormone, you are creating a diuretic effect. If Peter drinks too much too close to bed, he will actually take a low dose of vasopressin to offset that effect. The general rule of thumb is if someone is really struggling with nocturia, don’t drink anything for four hours before bed so you’re deliberately dehydrating yourself a little bit before bed.

title: Alcoholic fatty liver disease (AFLD)
content: There’s nothing that histologically or certainly radiographically is going to tell you if they have fatty liver disease, it’s from alcohol versus non-alcohol. AFLD, alcoholic fatty liver disease.

title: NAFLD and its diagnosis
content: Fructose is probably the single most important driver of NAFLD. The first clue we look at is the liver function tests. It’s kind of a misnomer. They’re not really markers of liver function. Alanine aminotransferase or ALT is probably our most sensitive reference. For someone who starts out with a 20 can easily go to a 30. You just have to really take a clear history of how much is that person drinking — Peter always ask how many drinks they have per week. Finally, if you want to confirm your suspicion of fatty liver, you will do an ultrasound.

title: Cumulative effect of ethanol and fructose on NAFLD
content: Is there a cumulative effect of ethanol and fructose? In other words…if somebody does consume alcohol and they’re not going to reduce their alcohol consumption, all things equal, does it make more sense for that person to restrict fructose? Or even vice versa: So somebody who consumes a lot of fructose in their diet, maybe they should dial back the ethanol since both might contribute to fatty liver. “I can’t tell you off the top of my head that I’ve seen data to tell me that that is the case, but boy, I’d be shocked if it wasn’t.” says Peter

title: Individual differences in alcohol metabolism
content: Let’s talk about two different things…First, is there a genetic difference between individuals in terms of alcohol consumption and alcohol metabolism? “No question. That’s a given.” The most obvious of that is people, and it’s almost always Asians, who have a deficiency of an enzyme called aldehyde dehydrogenase. They have certain alterations in coding regions for genes that produce that enzyme which is very important for metabolizing ethanol. The SNPs are in the ALDH2 gene, and they cause a huge reduction in this enzyme’s activity. If your heterozygous, you have mild symptoms. Homozygotes, meaning people who have two copies of this, usually can’t tolerate a single drink. Secondly, tolerance seems to go down as we age. College person having 10 drinks feels different than a middle aged person having the same, generally speaking. Peter suspects there are genetic differences here. We know for example, that we have very different metabolisms, genetically, for caffeine. That is also likely true in alcohol. There are different rates of alcohol metabolism that are genetic and it might be that those faster metabolizers are less impacted by the effect of alcohol on sleep. If you took two people, one is a fast metabolizer, one is a slow metabolizer. They both have three drinks, four hours before bed. One of them might be feeling the effects of all of that when they go to sleep, if they’re a slow metabolizer, the other might not be. Peter’s unsure what of the genetic SNPs that are responsible, so it’s probably something you just have figured out empirically as an individual. Would somebody who has developed a higher tolerance for alcohol through frequent consumption be able to metabolize it faster than they would if they hadn’t developed tolerance? There’s some evidence to suggest that chronic heavy drinkers (1–5 days weekly consumption of ≥5 drinks per occasion for men, ≥ 4 for women) absorb and metabolize alcohol faster than light drinkers (weekly drinkers who averaged consuming <6 drinks per week).

title: Effects of Food Composition on Alcohol Metabolism
content: Food composition affects alcohol metabolism through effects on absorption rate and elimination rate. A high-carb meal before alcohol intake appears to reduce peak BAL relative to a high-protein meal. When alcohol was administered IV, no differences in rate of alcohol elimination were identified between subjects who had consumed either a high-carb, high-protein, or high-fat meal of equal caloric value, but all groups that had consumed a meal exhibited faster elimination rates than those who had undergone a 12-hour fast.

title: Alcohol Metabolism on Ketogenic Diet
content: Anecdotally, some people who are on ketogenic diets say that they’re much more sensitive to alcohol. It might be that the liver ketogenic diet is doing a lot of glucogenesis and ketogenesis. And there’s some data that suggests that alcohol consumption will inhibit glucogenesis, and that’s sometimes why you see low blood sugar in somebody who is drinking. What’s possible is the liver is going to start to metabolize the alcohol to acetate and the brain can also use acetate for fuel. A 2021 study shows that it may be that there’s more acetate around and it’s hitting the brain, and these people speculated that some of that acetate metabolism may be what’s causing some of the inebriation in the brain.

title: Moderate Alcohol Consumption and Mortality
content: There are some epidemiologic studies to suggest that moderate alcohol consumption lowers mortality, but they have to be scrutinized pretty heavily. Many observational studies investigating the association between alcohol consumption and all-cause mortality (ACM), with inconsistent findings. A majority of studies found a J-shaped relationship, meaning that the nadir of mortality is not at the furthest left end of the graph. Inconsistent findings suggest that there is no clear benefit to some alcohol relative to no alcohol.

title: Methodological Issues
content: All of these are observational studies based on recall meaning there are no randomized control trials. Another problem is the selection bias in these studies. For example, the moderate drinkers have a higher socioeconomic status—higher education, higher income, more likely to exercise, more likely to eat a few fruits and vegetables. Never drinkers and the former drinkers that tend to be in a lower economic bracket, lower education, tend to have higher obesity, higher BMI, tend to of smoke more, etc.

title: Peter's Thoughts
content: It’s very difficult for me to believe that some alcohol is better than none. It’s possible that some alcohol is no worse than none in a healthy enough individual. The cohorts are older people so a “survivorship bias” occurs in these studies. To study a group of 30 and 40-year-olds, when you’re trying to understand mortality is going to be a pretty uninteresting study. A number of drinkers progress from light or moderate to heavy drinking over the years.

title: BMJ Study
content: In over a million participants separated out those who had drank previously from those who had never drank (i.e., never-drinkers), looking at outcomes (6y follow-up), and adjusted for age, sex, socioeconomic status, and smoking status (in the case of hazard ratios). The hypothesis was that the former drinkers likely quit because they had to for health reasons compared to people who have never had a drink. The key things the study looked at were all-cause mortality and cardiovascular death.

title: Results of BMJ Study
content: Hazard ratios (HRs) for all-cause mortality vs moderate drinking: Never-drinkers = 1.24 (95% CI, 1.20-1.28), suggesting moderate drinking is associated with longevity or less likely to die. Former drinker = 1.38 (95% CI, 1.30-1.47), suggesting that if we just take it at face value, that it seems like the former drinkers might be at higher risk than the people who never drink. Crude absolute risks (ARs) for all-cause mortality: 5.9% (70,074/1,195,351) AR in moderate drinker, 11.0% (30,553/277,042) AR in never-drinker, 9.6% (6,877/71,682) AR in former drinker.

title: Alcohol consumption and CVD death
content: The study found that never-drinkers had a 1.32 HR for CVD death, while former drinkers had a 1.44 HR. The crude AR for CVD death was 2.3% in never-drinkers and 1.9% in former drinkers, compared to 1.1% in moderate drinkers.

title: Peter Attia's thoughts on the 2017 study
content: Peter Attia expressed skepticism about the 2017 study, stating that the investigators likely did not account for confounding variables.

title: Alcohol consumption and Alzheimer's disease
content: The Rotterdam Study found that light-to-moderate drinking (1-3 drinks per day) was associated with a 42% reduction in any form of dementia and a 70% reduction in vascular dementia compared to never drinkers. However, the study did not adjust for exercise or nutrition habits.

title: Heavy alcohol consumption and risk of dementia
content: A study from Sweden with over 12,000 participants found that moderate to heavy drinkers had a 57% higher risk of dementia and a reduced onset of dementia by 4.76 years compared to light drinkers. Total abstainers were not different from light drinkers. Monozygotic twins who were moderate-to-heavy drinkers had 3x the risk for dementia versus light drinkers. Peter is skeptical of the idea that some alcohol is better for you than none, but acknowledges that a low enough dose may not pose much of an issue.

title: Alcohol and Health
content: Especially in The Rotterdam Study—the study that makes the strongest case for drinking… The legal drinking age for alcohol in the Netherlands is currently 18, but in 2014 it was age 16. Culturally, this suggests the culture is one that probably drinks quite responsibly, a culture that doesn’t have a lot of problems with excessive alcohol consumption, and this is probably a culture where alcohol is integrated into every aspect of life. Therefore not drinking alcohol is probably a marker for something odd. It’s probably like not having a sauna in Finland, meaning there’s likely something fundamentally different about the person who lives in Finland and doesn’t sauna (or lives in Rotterdam and doesn’t drink). My takeaway for this is if alcohol brings you great pleasure and there’s no maladaptive negative in your life, it’s probably a wash to have some alcohol versus to have none. If alcohol is a maladaptive coping strategy for you, then I think abstinence does make a ton of sense.

title: Chronic effects of alcohol on the liver
content: When looking at the epi data suggesting moderate drinking is potentially better than no drinking, this could create an issue with the public health messaging: So, we’re talking about the consumption of alcohol, all-cause mortality and all these problems and we’re looking at groups and we’re saying moderate drinking is better than never drinking at all. As a public health figure, you might run into this issue of telling a population of people who have never touched alcohol to start drinking moderately when almost assuredly there is going to be some proportion of those people that are going to go on to drink beyond moderately, and they’re going to run into some problems especially when there are a lot of problems with the way these studies are designed. Chronic effects of alcohol on the liver -Peter had Chris Sonneday on the podcast in the past… Chris talked about how we’re actually seeing a rise in alcoholic liver disease, AFLD, as a cause for cellular carcinoma and/or liver transplant. The story about NAFLD being on the rise is well understood. It’s gone up by more than 2X in the last decade. But what’s almost not noticed is that the same is true for alcohol. So in 2010, alcoholic liver disease was accounting for 13% of liver transplants in the United States while non-alcoholic liver disease was 9%. In the last year for which we have data (2019), alcoholic liver disease is up to 29% while NAFLD is up to 22%. Peter says it will be very interesting to note how these data change post COVID… “I would bet that alcoholic liver disease would’ve risen disproportionately to NAFLD in the presence of COVID.”

title: Alcohol, Sleep, and Automotive Deaths
content: Primary conditions that lead to fatalities are: alcohol, speeding, and distraction leading to a loss of control or contact with another vehicle. In the cases where drivers are killed on freeways… 31% of them have alcohol in their system and nearly 85% of these drivers were over the legal limit of 0.08 g/dL. But also think about the negative effects alcohol has on sleep quality, which could also increase the probability of driver error. When you understand how much poor sleep contributes to drowsy driving, which contributes to accidents, how much of that poor sleep could be underpinned by alcohol? “I don’t think we’ll ever know that, but it would suggest to me that this number of 31% and 85%, or 31% rather represents the floor to what this looks like.”

title: Alcohol and Performance
content: Peter Attia acknowledges that even a small amount of alcohol can affect reaction time and spatial awareness, which can be detrimental to performance in high-stakes environments such as driving a race car or simulator.

title: Driving and Reaction Time
content: Peter Attia emphasizes the importance of having good reaction time and awareness while driving, especially in sudden and potentially catastrophic situations.
